content: The "Teachers in the Classroom Act" may be cited as the short title. The Act includes findings. Congress finds that elementary and secondary school enrollment is at record levels, with an expected increase of over a million students in 1998. The trend is projected to continue with an additional 3 million students over the next decade, including a 13% increase in secondary school attendance. Increases in elementary and secondary student enrollment will continue in record numbers for the next decade, with over 3,000,000 additional students expected. This growth will impact high poverty urban and rural areas, as well as states with rapid population growth. Schools will need to hire 150,000 additional teachers to keep up with the increasing number of students. The unprecedented increase in student enrollment will impact high poverty urban and rural areas, as well as states with rapid population growth. Schools will need to hire 150,000 additional teachers to keep up with the growing number of students. Data from Project STAR suggests that small class sizes have positive effects on student learning and development. Data and research from Project STAR indicate that students in smaller classes in the early grades learn more, maintain an academic advantage even after returning to normal-sized classrooms, and show that adding students to a classroom diminishes learning for the rest of the class. It is crucial to adequately educate and prepare students. Congress needs to fund positions for teachers to improve the learning environment and keep pace with growing enrollment without adding to the Federal bureaucracy, deficit, or debt. Additionally, resources should be provided to help reduce classroom sizes. The grant program is established to fund positions for teachers and improve the learning environment without adding to the Federal bureaucracy, deficit, or debt. The Secretary of Education can award grants to Governors to hire teachers and reduce overcrowded classes. Governors must submit an application to be eligible for the grant. The Secretary cannot disapprove an application if funds are available. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a Governor must submit an application to the Secretary. The Secretary cannot disapprove an application if funds are available. Local educational agencies must establish a trust fund for payments received and deposit funds into the trust account. Local educational agencies must establish a trust fund for all payments received under this Act and deposit funds into the trust account. They must use the funds to hire new teachers or qualified personnel within 2 years and adhere to accounting practices specified by the Governor. The agency must also allow the State access to all records regarding the received funds. The agency must ensure that funds received under this Act are used to hire new teachers or qualified personnel within 2 years. They must follow accounting practices specified by the Governor and allow the State access to all records. Additionally, the agency must aim to increase the number of teachers or qualified instructional personnel in classrooms and review the performance of personnel hired annually to ensure they are qualified. The agency must ensure a net gain in teachers or qualified personnel, review their performance annually, limit their employment to one year, repay unused funds within 27 months, and use funds only as a supplement. The agency must also demonstrate the amount of non-Federal funds available for student education and apply to the Governor yearly for funding under this Act. SEC. 4. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS. Each State eligible to receive funds based on the average number of children aged 5 through 17. Unused funds reallocated to other States. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. A Governor can withhold payments to a local educational agency for noncompliance with section 3(c) provisions. Maintenance of Effort requires an increase in teachers or qualified personnel. SEC. 6. PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION. A Governor receiving a grant under this Act must select local educational agencies based on the need to alleviate overcrowded classes. They must also evaluate and report on the funds used by the agencies annually to the Secretary of Education. A Governor receiving a grant under this Act must evaluate and audit funds used by local educational agencies to alleviate overcrowded classes. They must report findings annually to the Secretary of Education and can use a maximum of 2% of the funds for administrative costs. Additionally, up to 10% of the funds can be used for innovative teaching programs. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with Governors, shall report to the Committee on the use of funds under this Act. Governors can allocate up to 2% for administrative costs and up to 10% for innovative teaching programs to improve instructional quality. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with Governors, shall report annually on the effectiveness of programs assisted under this Act and make recommendations for program continuity. SEC. 7. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not provide tenure to personnel hired under it. SEC. 8. DEFINITION. Defines "local educational agency," "State," and "Secretary." SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Act are as follows: $500,000,000 for fiscal year 1999, $1,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $1,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, $2,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, and $2,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2003.
